title: Making A Murderer Stephen Avery's lawyer wants new trial
text:
New information has come to light

The lawyer of Making a Murderer’s Stephen Avery said the murder of Teresa Halbach could go on trial again ‘in light of new information’.

As covered in Netflix’s Making a Murderer, Steven Avery and nephew Brendan Dassey have been convicted over the death, but multiple people have called that ruling into doubt.

Avery’s defence attorney Kathleen Zellner wholeheartedly believes in his innocence, and previously shared her theory regarding a piece of evidence that was briefly mentioned in season one of the documentary series, that she thinks is more important than first assumed.

Now Zellner has filed a 135-page document to the Wisconsin Appeals Court District II yesterday (Monday, October 14) that asks the court for a new trial.

In the document, she reiterates her theory and claims that Avery did not receive satisfactory counsel during the previous trial.

‘We are thrilled to have Steven’s brief filed,’ she tweeted, ‘and we look forward to the first unbiased, fair and competent review of these issues.’

Zellner goes into detail about how the circuit court dismissed Avery’s requests for additional scientific testing at the time and highlights several mistakes she believes they made.

She also mentions DNA and the ‘blood spatter’ in the report. She claims Avery’s attorney failed to call experts on the blood spatter found in Teresa Halbach’s vehicle.

Avery claimed that blood from a cut in his finger was taken from his sink and planted in the vehicle.

‘Suspiciously, there were no bloody fingerprints of Mr. Avery in or on the RAV-4 despite the fact that he could not have been wearing gloves when he allegedly deposited blood from the cut on his finger in the RAV-4,’ reads the brief.

New evidence has come to light (Picture: Netflix)

The lawyer also refers to Bryan Dassey’s testimony as he told police that Bobby saw Teresa Halbach leave the property, however in court Bobby testified that he saw Halbach walking towards Steven Avery’s house on the day of the murder, two statements which contradict each other.

Avery has previously been denied a new trial multiple times.

Zellner has previously offered a reward for the arrest of the ‘real’ killer of Teresa Halbach.

Sharing the news with her Twitter followers, she tweeted: ‘We are pleased to announce that a reward of $100,000 (£82,000) is being offered, by a concerned citizen, for the arrest and conviction of the real killer of Teresa Halbach.’

Following that, a handwritten murder confession was submitted, but Zellner has claimed that it is not genuine.
